Graphical abstract Ni-based catalysts promoted by Rh were prepared from hydrotalcite-type (Ht) precursors and employed in Dry Reforming (DR) and combined Steam/Dry Reforming (S/DR) of clean biogas (CB, an equimolar mixture of CH4 and CO2) to produce syngas suitable for Fischer-Tropsch or methanol synthesis. The structure of the catalysts before and after reaction were thoroughly characterized by XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, Raman, TG and TEM techniques. The DR results showed that the addition of a small amount of Rh increased the CO2 conversion and significantly decreased the carbon formation. The addition of steam to the feed to perform the combined S/DR reaction promoted the catalyst activity further by improving its resistance to carbon deposition and therefore of minimising deactivation. XRD and TPR analyses showed that an increase of the amount of Mg in the catalytic formulation, improve the active phase stability through the formation of MgO-NiO solid solution by calcination. Keywords Biogas Ni-based catalysts Steam reforming Dry reforming Syngas 1 Introduction The steam reforming (SR) of natural gas (NG) plays a crucial role in the industrial production of syngas (CO + H2) or hydrogen. CO2 and hydrogen are widely used in industrial chemical processes to produce building block chemicals for the production of fine chemicals, fuels and energy. The depletion of fossil fuels together with the environmental drawbacks associated to the utilisation of these sources, have prompted in the last decades to the study of new and renewable fuels. One of the main candidates to replace the natural gas is the biogas. Biogas (BG) is produced by anaerobic digestion of a large variety of biological wastes in different environments such as landfills [1,2], sewage sludge [3–5] or biowaste digesters [5–7] with a variable chemical composition. BG production and upgrading plants are spread all around the world together with the demand of high quality biomethane to be used as a potential chemical for vehicle fuel utilisation or for injection in the NG grid [8–10]. The leading countries in Europe in the BG production are Germany, UK, Italy, Czech Republic and France, with Germany that covers about 50% of the EU annual production [11]. After its purification, the clean biogas (CB) is a mixture of methane and carbon dioxide [12] and can be used for many purposes such as production of heat or steam [13,14], electricity [15,16], syngas or hydrogen [17]. Although the removal of the CO2 to obtain biomethane, that can be directly introduced in energy grid it is a feasible way to exploit the CB [18–20], a full valorisation of its composition is more desirable from both economic and environmental point of view. In this context, the utilization of the CB in the SR process: CH4 + H2O ↔ CO + 3H2 ΔHr298K = +207 kJ/mol appears to be an attractive option, but the CO2 stream is hardly converted in the conditions in which the industrial process is carried out (high content of steam in the feed) decreasing the productivity of the plant [21,22]. From this point of view, the Dry Reforming (DR) reaction: CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2H2 ΔHr298K = +247 kJ/mol can represent an appealing way to produce syngas from CB [23]. However, a number of drawbacks of this process exist, such as high reaction temperatures and fast coke formation [24–28] that limits its commercialization [29]. One of the possible solutions to overcome the main drawbacks associated to the DR process is the addition of an oxidant to the reaction feed. The use of pure oxygen [30,31] can however limits the safety of the plant [32] while the addition of air or steam [31] is more feasible. The combination of SR and DR in a one-step can be represented with the following equation: CH4 + x H2O + (1-x) CO2 ↔ (2-x) CO + (2+x) H2 where x = 1 is the SR, while x = 0 is the DR. This process, named combined Steam/Dry Reforming (S/DR), allows to valorise the CO2-content of the CB, limiting the deactivation phenomena without changing the established industrial technologies. About this latter, from at least 20 years it is practiced in industry the reforming of natural gas in the presence of CO2 to improve the amounts of CO formed, see for example the SPARG [33–35] or the CALCOR [36,37] processes. In the present study a higher CO2 amount was co-fed, showing that the combined reforming allows to fully exploit the clean biogas and not only the biomethane fraction, with a better environmental balance. The harsh reaction conditions associated with these reforming processes are challenging environments for the industrial heterogenous catalysts in terms of deactivation and stability and long-term performance. In this context, the properties of the catalyst in terms of particle size, metal oxidation state, and the right choice of the active phase and catalytic support, play an important role to enhance the catalyst life and perform catalytic reactions at milder reaction conditions. Noble and transition metal-based catalysts were extensively investigated to promote the endothermic reforming reactions [38–41]. Although the high activity and resistance to deactivation of noble metal catalysts, Ni-based catalysts (100–150 times cheaper than noble metals) are more widely used in industrial applications [42,43]. However, the high carbon formation associated with the use of these catalysts lead to their deactivation in short period and therefore causing a higher operational drawback. Although the preparation of Ni/Al or Ni/Mg/Al catalysts from hydrotalcite-type (HT) precursors has been reported for the first time about 50 years ago [44] and after referred in many relevant reviews [45–53], it remains a promising way to develop new compositions with improved catalytic performances and combined for example with the presence of low amounts of noble metals. Starting from these considerations, in the present work the valorisation of CB through S/DR reaction over Ni-based catalysts is reported to be an achievable pathway to overcome the main drawbacks associated to the DR alone. In this context the promotion of the active phase by small amounts of Rh together with a fine tuning of active sites – support interactions were deeply investigated. 2 Experimental The Ni/Rh/Mg/Al catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation of hydrotalcite-type (Ht) precursors using the following experimental procedure: i) Preparation of a M2+ (Ni2+,Mg2+) and M3+ (Al3+, Rh3+) nitrate solution [2 M] and of a Na2CO3 [1 M] solution in deionized water; ii) Co-precipitation by dropwise addition of the metal nitrate solution into a well stirred Na2CO3 solution at controlled temperature (60 °C) and pH (10). The pH was kept constant during the synthesis by dropwise addition of a 3 M solution of NaOH; iii) Aging of the solid at the synthesis conditions for 60 min; iv) The obtained precipitate was filtered and washed by a large amount of deionized water up to a residual Na2O content < 0.01 wt. % in the precipitate dried at 70 °C for 12 h; v) Calcination of the solid at 900 °C for 6 h. The label of the final catalysts derived from the following nomenclature are presented in Table 1 : XNiMgAlY_RhZ where: X = Ni wt.%, Y = M2+/M3+ atomic ratio; Z = Rh wt.% The calcined catalysts were pressed at 10 t for 20 min and pelletised, crushed and sieved to obtain particles in the range 30–40 mesh. The catalysts (≈ 1 g, catalytic bed =3 cm) were loaded between two layers of inert material (quartz) in a tubular reactor (INCOLOY 800 H T) with an internal diameter of 8 mm, vertically placed into an electric tubular furnace. The laboratory scale plant consisted in four gas lines (CH4, CO2, N2, H2, controlled by thermal mass flow controllers) and a steam generator operating at 215 °C. The unreacted water was completely separated from the exit stream by a cooled gas liquid separator maintained at 1 °C by cryogenic system. The operating pressure was controlled by a pressure controller (BROOKS instruments) placed after the condenser, while the gas stream was sent to the analysis section. The gas flows were measured by a gas flowmeter and the composition of the stream was analysed by an online gas chromatograph (Agilent Technology 7890A GC) equipped with a CarboPLOT P7 (carrier gas: H2, 27.5 m/ 750 μm/25 μm) and a HP-Molesieve (carrier gas: N2, 30 m/ 530 μm/50 μm) columns and two Thermal Conductivity Detectors (TCD). Before the catalytic tests, the reduction of the catalyst was carried out in situ feeding a continuous flow of H2/N2 (1/10 v/v) at 0.5 MPa, increasing the oven temperature from 300 °C to 900 °C (10 °C/min) and holding this temperature for 1 h. The tests were carried out feeding an equimolar mixture of CH4 and CO2 at 0.5 MPa. The experimental conditions used for the DR reaction were WHSV = 25,000 ml/(h*gcat) and Toven = 700, 800, 900 °C. The internal reaction temperature of the catalytic bed during reaction were carefully measured by a capillary thermocouple sliding a capillary inserted inside the catalytic bed. Examples of temperature profiles are reported in supporting information (Fig. S1). The calculations for the thermodynamic equilibrium were performed considering the outlet temperature of the catalytic bed for every condition tested, using the CEAgui software (NASA). Table 2 reports the experimental conditions used in the S/DR tests, after the full cycle. A test at the same reaction conditions of the first one was performed to evaluate the catalyst deactivation. The catalysts were characterized before and after reaction by several characterisation techniques. The XRD powder analysis was carried out using a PANalytical X’Pert diffractometer equipped with a copper anode (Cu Kα, λ =0.15418 nm) and a fast X’Celerator detector. A 2θ range from 5° to 80° was investigated, using a step size of 0.1° and a time per step of 2 s. The surface area values of the catalysts were determined by N2-physisorption at −196 °C by Braunauer-Emmer-Teller (BET) method using a Carlo Erba Sorpty instrument. The sample (0.3 g) was pre-treated at 150 °C under vacuum and analysed in a liquid bath of N2. The Raman spectroscopy analyses were performed using a Renishaw RM1000 instrument equipped with a microscope to focus the beam in the zone of interest. The beam laser used was green (Ar+ 514.5 nm) with a relative power of 10% to avoid the oxidation of the carbon eventually present. The spectra were recorded in the region 2000 – 800 cm−1, with an acquisition time of 10 s and a total of 10 accumulations. Transmission electron microscopy characterization was carried out by a TEM/STEM FEI TECNAI F20 microscope, equipped with an EDS analyser. Powder catalysts were suspended in ethanol under ultrasound for 20 min. The suspension was subsequently deposited on an Au grid with lacey multi-foil carbon film and dried at 100 °C before doing the measurement. The distribution of the nanoparticles was determined by statistical distribution of at least 200 particle diameters. TGA analyses were carried out on a TA instrument Q600 equipped with a FT-IR after the heating chamber for the analyses of the gases evolved during the experiments. 8–10 mg of sample were placed in an alumina pan, heated up to 900 °C (10 °C/min) and kept constant for 10 min at this temperature under a continuous flow of synthetic air (100 ml/min). The reduction and desorption profiles (TPR/TPO) were measured using a Micromeritics AutoChem II Chemisorption Analyzer, equipped with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). The analyses were carried out loading ≈ 100 mg of sample in a quartz reactor and using two different procedures for H2-TPR and CO2-TPD experiments. H2-TPR experiments were performed pre-treating the sample under He (30 mL/min) from room temperature (r.t.) to 500 °C (10 °C/min) and hold at this temperature for 1 h. After cooling to 35 °C, the reduction analysis was performed using a 5% H2/Ar (v/v) mixture (30 mL/min), increasing the temperature of the sample to 900 °C (10 °C/min) and keeping this temperature for 1 h. The CO2-TPD experiments were conducted pre-treating the sample under He from r.t. to 500 °C (10 °C/min) and hold at this temperature for 2 h. The CO2 adsorption was carried out after cooling to 40 °C, using a 10% CO2/Ar (v/v) mixture at constant temperature for 2 h. The physisorbed CO2 was removed by He purging for 1 h. Then, the sample was heated up to 900 °C (10 °C/min) under a stream of He, while the desorbed CO2 was monitored and recorder using an online Mass Spectrometer (Cirrus 2, MKS instruments), that was calibrated by manual injections of pure CO2 pulses. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dry reforming of clean biogas To point out the main disadvantages of the DR reaction, the catalytic performance of two catalysts (10NiMgAl3 and 10NiMgAl3_Rh05) was carried out feeding an equimolar mixture of CH4 and CO2. The dried Ht precursors transformed during calcination to a mixture of oxides composed by Mg, Al, Ni and Rh (Fig. S2). The difficulty to discriminate between the NiO, MgO and MgAl2O4, NiAl2O4 phases was due to the overlapping of their characteristic peaks enhanced by the broadening of the peaks due the low crystallinity. The catalytic tests were carried out at 700–800 °C and showed the presence of a high carbon formation with a critical increase of the pressure drop due to the breakage of the catalyst granules. The presence of the characteristic G, D and D2 Raman bands [54] confirmed the presence of carbon deposited on the catalysts surface (Fig. 5 a and b, see below); the presence of carbon was also detectable by XRD (Fig. S3) by the presence of the peak at 26.18°2θ, attributable to the 002 plane (Reference pattern 00-001-0640) [55]. The results of the activity tests are reported in Table 3 while the equilibrium curves calculated in terms of CH4, CO2 conversion and Carbon formation as a function of the temperature are presented in Fig.1 . The CB conversion increased with the increase of temperature (reaching value near to the equilibrium in case of tests conducted at 800 °C) and the best catalytic results were obtained by promoting the catalyst by Rh (0.5% wt). In the latter case, the H2/CO molar ratios of the outlet syngas were lower than 1 due to the occurrence of the Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction that increased the CO2 conversion from the unit value expected from the DR reaction. Performing the catalytic tests at 900 °C it was possible to increase significantly the catalyst life, reducing the carbon deposition and enhancing the catalyst activity (Fig. 2 ). Although not-promoted (Fig. 2a) and Rh-promoted (Fig. 2b) samples did not show any deactivation during with time-on-stream, the latter still evidenced the best catalytic performances. The different catalytic behaviours may be related to the influence of Rh on the mean particle size and metal particle distribution after reduction (Fig. S4). The addition of a 0.5 wt.% of Rh gave rise to a distribution centred around a value of 7 nm without the presence of particles larger than 10 nm while the non-promoted catalyst showed a significant presence of metal particles larger than 14 nm and the mean particle size was increased of ≈ 70% (12 nm). The dispersion of the metallic Ni and Rh particles(active phase) was related to the reducibility of the catalysts. The H2-TPR analyses on the two calcined catalysts (Fig. 3 ) showed that the presence of Rh had two main effects: i) a slight decrease of the Ni2+ reduction temperature from 900 °C (undoped sample) to 895 °C within experimental error; ii) a symmetrical shape of the Ni2+ reduction profile. On the contrary, a broad peak of Ni2+ reduction was observed for the undoped sample, showing a low degree of reducibility with formation of large and not well distributed Ni0 particles. The presence of a peak at 370 °C observed for the 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 catalyst may be associated to the reduction of Rh3+ species weakly interacting with the support. The H2 consumption for the undoped catalysts corresponds to 68% of Ni2+ reduction to Ni0 species. The temperature related to the maximum of the peak (Tm) and the incomplete reduction of the metal may be ascribed to the following reasons: i)the amount and distribution of Ni particles that cause a shift of the Tm to higher values; ii) the method of synthesis that could not allow to the complete exposure of Ni particles after calcination; iii) the calcination temperature that may favour the strong interaction between metal and support, especially Ni/Al/O. Rh acts as a promoter for the Ni2+ reduction enhancing nucleation of reduced species and H2 spill-over; in the latter case the shape and Tm of the Ni reduction profile are affected. Concerning the H2 consumption, the first peak corresponds to 33% of Rh reduction and the second to 81% of Ni reduction (if considered for the only Ni2+ reduction) or about 70% of Rh and about 70% of Ni [56–59]. The TEM images on the spent catalysts showed the presence of long and well distributed carbon nanotubes for the 10NiMgAl3 catalyst, together with the formation of graphitic carbon encapsulating some Ni0 particles (Fig. 4 ). Although the detachment of some Ni0 particles from the support due to the generation of carbon nanotubes was observed for the 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 spent catalyst (Fig. 4 on the right), their presence was small, not homogeneous along the sample and without clear evidence of encapsulating carbon. The harsh reaction conditions and the high temperature promoted the sintering of the active phase for both of the catalysts with an increase of metal particle size and therefore of metal particle distribution, with the presence of particles larger than 60 nm. From the EDX analyses the formation of a Ni-Rh alloy with particle size-depending composition was observed (Fig. S5). As shown in Table 4 , in which the metal composition in the centre of the particles as a function of their diameter is reported, the Rh content varied from a value of 2% in the 25 nm particles to a value around 66% in the smaller particles (diameter =3 nm). TGA analyses (Fig. 5c and d) confirmed that the presence of Rh improved significantly the catalyst resistance to carbon formation, showing a low mass loss of ≈ 3 wt.% for the doped Ni catalyst, versus a significant higher value of ≈ 25 wt. % for the undoped Ni catalyst. Further evidence was obtained by XRD (Fig. S6) and Raman analyses (Fig. 5c and d). The intensity of the G, D ad D2 Raman bands (Fig. 5c) for the sample 10NiMgAl3 were more intense with respect to the bands showed by the sample containing Rh (Fig. 5d) in which it was possible to reveal very low and sharp G and D bands not homogeneously distributed on the catalyst surface. Summarizing the experimental evidences reported above, it is possible to point out some important characteristics of the catalysts that must be considered to overcome the main drawbacks and challenges of the DR reaction. Performing the reaction without any oxidant it is not possible to avoid the carbon deposition on the surface of the catalysts even if at 900 °C was significantly reduced. The addition of Rh led to two main effects: i) reduction of the mean particle size through the formation of a binary Ni/Rh alloy that increases the reducibility of the catalyst and the active phase area favouring the activity and ii) significant decrease of the carbon deposition and therefore increasing the catalyst life. 3.2 Addition of steam: combined steam/dry reforming reaction (S/DR) The 10NiMgAl3 and 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 catalysts were tested in the S/DR conditions, changing the reaction parameters, evaluating the effect of Rh on the catalyst properties and discriminating the main reaction differences between the two reforming (Steam and Dry, SR and DR) processes. The CH4 and CO2 conversion curves calculated at the thermodynamic equilibrium as a function of the operating conditions are showed in Fig. 6 . The role of steam was at first evaluated by testing on the 10NiMgAl3 catalyst. In this case the catalytic performances were evaluated by decreasing the temperature from 900 to 700 °C, varying the value of the Steam/CH4 ratio (S/CH4) in the feed (2.0, 1.0, 0.5 v/v), but maintaining constant the WHSV value. The preliminary catalytic results obtained in the combined process are showed in Fig. 7 . The increase in CH4 conversion (≈ 98%) in the test conducted at 900 °C (S/CH4 = 2.0) together with a decrease in the CO2 conversion (≈ 33%), due to the occurrence of the SR reaction, was not maintained when, after two hours of time-on-stream, the S/CH4 ratio decreased to a value of 1 and a strong deactivation of the catalyst was observed (ΔCH4 conversion = -75%, ΔCO2 conversion = -33%). This catalytic performance may be attributed mainly to the re-oxidation of the active phase due to the presence of steam at high temperature, and for this reason the catalyst was subjected to a further in-situ reduction. After this step, the catalytic activity was recovered in a following test (T =900 °C, S/CH4 = 0.5) in which the CB conversions were stable over 2 h. However, after a further change of the reaction conditions (T =800 °C, S/CH4 = 2.0), another dramatic drop of activity and long term performance was observed, confirming the instability of this catalyst. The XRD patterns of the spent catalyst (Fig. 8 ) showed the characteristic reflections of the MgO-NiO solid solution and MgAl2O4, without the presence of Ni0 and NiAl2O4 phases, together with an increase of crystallinity, confirmed by a decrease of the BET specific surface area from 100 m2/g for the fresh catalyst to 43 m2/g for the spent catalyst. Comparing the XRD patterns in 41–46° 2θ region between the fresh and spent catalysts, it was possible to observe only a weak shift of the diffraction peak at 43° 2θ ca. towards lower Bragg angles in the spent catalyst, suggesting that only a small amount of NiO was steadily reduced during the S/DR reaction. On the contrary, in the XRD patterns of the same catalysts after DR reaction (spectrum c), it was possible to detect the diffraction peak at 42.8° 2θ that perfectly matched the MgO pattern, accompanied by the diffraction peak at 44.4° 2θ characteristic of Ni0 that confirmed the complete segregation of the NiO from the periclase phase. The 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 catalyst, with the best performances in the DR, was then tested in the combined S/DR reaction. The addition of Rh stabilized the catalyst activity without evidence of deactivation as a function of time-on-stream. The CH4 and CO2 conversions (Fig. 9 a, b) were both favoured at high temperature, but the respective values varied considerably changing the reaction parameters. The amount of steam affected the H2/CO ratio in the produced synthesis gas, (Fig. 9c), that increased lowering the temperature at high S/CH4 values, due to the predominance of the SR on the DR reaction. On the other hand, when the S/CH4 ratio was low, the H2/CO ratio decreased and was not significantly affected by the reaction temperature, reaching values near 1 in the conditions promoting the CO2 conversion. The presence of Rh affected the mean particle size and metal particle distribution of the active phase after reaction, with a particle size distribution between 2 and 9 nm range and a mean particle size centred around 4 nm (Fig. S7), significantly lower than the value found after the DR (16 nm). After reaction Raman (Fig. S7) and TGA analyses revealed a weak presence of carbon not homogenously distributed, lower than 0.5% of the catalyst weight. Even in S/DR conditions, the formation of Ni-Rh alloy was observed, although in this case its composition was more homogeneous by varying the particle size and aggregates with different diameter showed only small differences of Rh and Ni content (Fig. S8). A fine tuning of the catalyst properties to boost the CB conversion may be obtained by varying the support metal composition. In this context, the basicity of the catalyst could play a key role, favouring the CO2 adsorption and conversion on the active sites. The influence of the support composition on the catalytic activity and stability of the Ni-Rh catalyst in the S/DR reaction was studied by changing the M2+/M3+ molar ratio in the catalyst formulation, increasing the Mg-content to the upper limit of the Ht-precursor [45], therefore, the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 precursor was synthesized. The specific surface area values of the calcined catalysts were 107 m2/g for both 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 and 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 samples and the calcined catalysts showed comparable diffraction patterns in terms of diffraction peak positions (Fig S9), while the intensity of the diffraction peaks varied according to the Mg and Al content, with MgO peak more intense for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 calcined catalyst. The XRD patterns of the samples at 41–46 º and 60–65 º 2θ (Fig. 10 ) showed that, increasing the M2+/M3+ ratio, an increasing shift of the reflections at 2θ = 43.0° and 62.4° ca. towards higher Bragg angles (typical of the NiO pattern) occurred, indicating the formation of a solid solution. This behaviour is reflected on the amount of NiO present on the surface affecting its reduction temperature and the intensity of the peak. The reduction of the catalysts took place in two different regions; the first broad peak may be attributed to the reduction of the Rh3+ ions weakly interacting with the support (366–374 °C region), while the intense peaks at high temperature may be ascribed to the reduction of NiO (892–895 °C region) (Fig. S10). The sample 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 showed a first reduction peak at 366 °C attributable to Rh reduction (Reduced Rh2O3 (%) = 19,42) and a second peak at 895 °C attributable to the Ni/Rh/O reduction (Reduced NiO (%) = 79,19; Reduced Rh2O3 (%) = 80,58) while the sample 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 showed a reduction peak attributable to Rh reduction at 374 °C (Reduced Rh2O3 (%) = 33,22) and a peak attributable to the reduction of Ni/Rh/O at 892 °C (Reduced NiO (%) = 86,23; Reduced Rh2O3 (%) = 64,78). From the above reported results, it is possible to strengthen the hypothesis that the amount of MgO-NiO mixed oxide increases with the Mg content, lowering the amount of NiO present on the catalyst surface that could be reduced under H2-TPR conditions. The distribution and dispersion of the metal particles after reduction obtained by TEM observations (Fig. S11) showed that the active phase is well distributed on the catalyst surface with a particle size of the produced nanoparticles comprised in the range 2–10 nm, without any presence of large agglomerates. The mean particle size decreased gradually at higher Mg concentration (39.0% wt). The catalytic results together with the temperature measured at the outlet of the catalytic bed are presented in Table 5 . The 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 catalyst showed a higher CH4 conversion compared to that of the 10NiMgAl3_Rh05 one, (Fig. 9a), mainly at lower reaction temperatures and S/CH4 ratios. A similar catalytic trend can be observed in the CO2 conversion (Fig. 9b), although the presence of many side reactions that involve in the transformation of the reactant make the control of selectivity challenging. Increasing the Mg-content the CO2 conversion slightly improved, especially at lower temperatures and S/CH4 values, for which the DR reaction was favoured (i.e. T =800 °C, S/CH4 = 1.0-0.5). The H2/CO molar ratio reported in Fig. 9c, did not show significant differences in the catalyst behaviour. In most of reaction conditions the produced syngas is suitable for further downstream applications such as Fischer-Tropsch or methanol synthesis, without needing a further Water Gas Shift (WGS) step to increase the yield in H2. The improved activity of the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 catalyst may be correlated to the basicity of the support [60–63]. The CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. 11 a) of the catalysts before reaction showed a clear difference between the two samples in terms of CO2 adsorption and, consequently, of support basicity. The intensity of the peaks increased with the Mg-content and three main desorption regions can be observed. The low temperature desorption peaks (110–120 °C) may be assigned to bicarbonate species formed on surface OH groups (weak basic sites); the middle temperature broad peaks (120–250 °C) to bidentate carbonates desorbed from Mg2+-O2− pairs, while the high temperature peaks (> 250 °C), clearly visible in the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 desorption profile, may be associated to the monodentate carbonates released from low-coordination O2− anions (strong basic sites) [64,65]. By integrating the two curves, the total amount of adsorbed CO2 was calculated for each catalyst (Fig. 11b), showing that the CO2 adsorption approximately doubled when the M2+/M3+ molar ratio was increased from 3 to 4. The deactivation of the catalysts was monitored at the end of each test cycle (Fig. S12) without observing any appreciable deactivation for both catalysts. The Raman spectra of the spent catalysts (Fig. S13) showed negligible presence of carbon regardless of the composition, such as confirmed by the TGA analyses. These results are in agreement with the calculated curves that shows the theoretical upper limit for the carbon formation at the thermodynamic equilibrium (Fig. 12 ), the addition of steam lowers in all the cases the carbon deposition as expected, that become negligible for S/CH4> 2.0 in the reaction conditions. The particle size distribution obtained by TEM images of the catalysts after reaction (Fig. S14), did not show any significant changes for the two samples. According to the results previously discussed, the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts showed an increase of the crystallinity (Fig. 13 ) without detectable diffraction peaks attributable to the presence of Ni0, probably due to its high dispersion. A shift of the two diffraction peaks at 2θ = ca 43.0 and 62.4° to lower Bragg angles (typical of the MgO pattern) was observed for both the used catalysts, suggesting a segregation of Ni0 from the MgO-NiO solid solution, leading to the formation of stable Ni nanoparticles strongly interacting with the support. Thus, the composition of the support affected significantly the catalytic properties in the S/DR reaction. The increase of the Mg-content in the formulation decreased the reducibility of the NiO phase but improved the interaction between the Ni-Rh particles and the oxide, due to the formation of a NiO-MgO solid solution by calcination. This phenomenon, together with the presence of strong basic sites on the surface of the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 catalyst, improved the dispersion of the active phase increasing its activity and resistance to the sintering processes. In order to shed light on the role of the Rh-content, its amount was varied from 0.0 to 1.4 wt.% using the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 catalyst as reference (Table 6 ). The specific surface area and crystallinity of the calcined samples were not influenced by changing the Rh-content, as confirmed by the XRD patterns (not reported), that did not show appreciable differences. The Ni-Rh interaction was studied by H2-TPR experiments (Fig. 14 ); the increase in Rh-content gave rise to a shift of the NiO reduction peak towards lower temperatures together with an increase of the TCD signal intensity, as stated for the above described samples. The peak associated to the reduction of Rh3+ species was visible only at high metal concentration, with a reduction temperature that increased with the Rh content. The H2 consumption associated to the reduction of both Rh and Ni oxides are reported in Table 7 . The values reported in the table indicate that the role of Rh is the promotion of reducibility of NiO by increasing the rate of nucleation of reduced metal on the particle and favouring the H2 spill over. This results in a strong decrease of the Tm of the second reduction peak. The amount of NiO reduced does not match with the total amount of Ni introduced during the synthesis of the catalyst. This discrepancy may be attributed to the high degree of difficulty to reduce the NiO that after calcination does not segregate to the catalyst surface remaining hindered in the support lattice. The increase degree of reducibility of the catalysts led to a different dispersion of the active phase after reduction [56–59]. The mean particle size of the metal particles decreased considerably by increasing the Rh-content and the centre of the statistical distributions (Fig. 15 ) moved from a value of 16 nm (10NiMgAl4) to 5-4 nm for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 and 10NiMgAl4_Rh14 catalysts, respectively. The dispersion trend strongly affected the activity of the catalysts, with CH4 conversion values (Fig. 16 a) that showed that the addition of increasing amounts of Rh greatly improved the performance of the catalysts, mainly at low reaction temperature. A comprehensive overview of the catalytic results is showed in Table 8 , in which the CB conversion is compared with the theoretical equilibrium values calculated at the outlet temperature of the catalytic bed. Although the activity differences were low approaching the thermodynamic equilibrium conditions (T =900 °C, S/CH4 = 2), a significant improvement was observed for the other experimental conditions tested, with an increase higher than 100% at 700–800 °C and S/CH4 ratios of 1.0-0.5. The addition of a low amount of Rh (0.03 wt.%) was sufficient to increase the CH4 conversion, especially at low steam contents. The further addition of Rh to 0.5 wt.% additionally improved the catalytic performance, reaching high conversion values in all the reaction conditions presented in this study. The catalytic results obtained for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh14 catalyst were comparable to those observed for the previous catalyst, suggesting that over a limit value of Rh (> 0.5 wt.%), a plateau in the activity was reached, and a further addition of Rh did not improve the CB conversion. A similar behaviour was observed for the CO2 conversion values, that showed high and comparable activities for 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 and 10NiMgAl4_Rh14 catalysts (Fig. 16b) The presence of Rh significantly improved the CO2 conversion at 700–800 °C, favouring the DR reaction at low S/CH4 values, with further some DR activity also at S/CH4 = 2.0, as confirmed by the lower H2/CO values obtained (Fig. 16c). The composition of the produced syngas did not show significant differences among the catalysts, although it seemed variable in the conditions in which the CB conversions were low, where the H2/CO values exceed values of 3 due to the occurrence of the WGS reaction, especially for the catalysts with low Rh-content. The presence of Rh affected also the stability of the catalysts (Table 9 a). A strong deactivation was observed for the Rh-free catalyst, probably also due to a partial re-oxidation already previously observed. The loss in activity decreased by increasing the Rh-content, reaching a high-level of stability for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 and 10NiMgAl4_Rh14 catalysts. It is noteworthy that in any case the deactivation values in terms of CO2 conversion were always higher than those in CH4 conversion. The carbon formed during the reaction determined by TGA analyses (Table. 9b) followed the same trend, with maximum formation for 10NiMgAl4 (mass lost 0.98%), although not able to fully justify the deactivations observed. The instability of the catalyst was mainly due to the sintering of the active phase, suppressed by the presence of Rh for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh05 and 10NiMgAl4_Rh14 samples. The distributions of the nanoparticles obtained by the TEM images of the catalysts after reaction (Fig. S15) showed the strong relevance of this phenomenon for the Rh-free catalyst, with the formation of large Ni(0) particles with a diameter over 150 nm, that notably decreased the metallic surface area, and a distribution centre of the smaller nanoparticles shifted from 16 to 18 nm after reaction. The extent of the sintering process was lower for the 10NiMgAl4_Rh003, although the formation of large agglomerates of ≈ 80 nm was observed together with a broadening in the dispersion of the active phase. The deactivation of the catalysts was hence related to mean particle size of Ni and the increase of the Rh content to 0.5–1.4 wt.% suppressed the sintering of the active phase, due to higher formation of the Ni-Rh alloy. 4 Conclusions The S/DR was demonstrated to be a suitable process to valorise the CB, producing syngas with the desired H2/CO ratio for Fischer-Tropsch or Methanol synthesis. The main drawbacks evidenced by the 10NiMgAl3 catalyst undergoing the DR reaction were used as starting points to properly tune the reaction conditions and define the catalyst compositions. The carbon formation, high in the DR reaction, was limited significantly by the addition of steam that allowed to extend the catalyst life and to obtain a syngas with the required composition. The overcoming of the DR drawbacks was realized studying the effect of the reaction conditions on the active site evolution, that allowed to synthesize catalysts with tailor made compositions to avoid the deactivation and convert both CH4 and CO2. Increasing the M2+/M3+ atomic ratio from 3 to 4 (and consequently the basicity of the catalyst) favoured the increase of the CB conversion due to the enhanced affinity of the CO2 with the catalytic surface and favoured the evolution of a highly dispersed, stable and more reducible Ni-Rh nanoparticles The presence of 0.5 wt.% of Rh produced active sites able to convert CB and enough stable to preserve its structural properties after several catalytic tests, without strong evidence of deactivation. The formation of a stable Ni-Rh alloy was favoured also by the increased basicity of the support, that allowed to obtain a highly disperse active phase. The correct modulation of the catalyst formulation was crucial to obtain the Ni-Rh alloy, that has a high activity and long term catalytic performance due to the role of Rh to promote the Ni reduction. coredata.dc:description: Ni-based catalysts promoted by Rh were prepared from hydrotalcite-type (Ht) precursors and employed in Dry Reforming (DR) and combined Steam/Dry Reforming (S/DR) of clean biogas (CB, an equimolar mixture of CH4 and CO2) to produce syngas suitable for Fischer-Tropsch or methanol synthesis. The structure of the catalysts before and after reaction were thoroughly characterized by XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, Raman, TG and TEM techniques. The DR results showed that the addition of a small amount of Rh increased the CO2 conversion and significantly decreased the carbon formation. The addition of steam to the feed to perform the combined S/DR reaction promoted the catalyst activity further by improving its resistance to carbon deposition and therefore of minimising deactivation. XRD and TPR analyses showed that an increase of the amount of Mg in the catalytic formulation, improve the active phase stability through the formation of MgO-NiO solid solution by calcination.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-based catalysts to produce synthesis gas by combined reforming of clean biogas
